item.title: Bangladesh Puts Its Eggs in One Economic Basket. Now, a Reckoning.
item.description: Garment exports lifted the country to new heights. But overreliance on that industry also helped bring down Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A garment factory on the outskirts of Dhaka, Bangladesh, last year.

item.title: What We Know About the Crash of VoePass Flight 2283 in Brazil
item.description: The twin-engine turboprop passenger aircraft crashed near São Paulo, killing all 61 people on board. Officials are investigating the cause.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: A view of the site of the plane crash in Vinhedo, Brazil, on Friday.

item.title: As Ukraine Pushes Deeper Into Russia, Moscow Sends Reinforcements
item.description: The Ukrainian police said they were evacuating people, perhaps in anticipation of a retaliatory strike, but the goal of the military operation on Russian territory remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Anatoliy Zhdanov/Kommersant Photo, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Russian tank outside Sudzha, Russia, on Thursday. The Ukrainian Army has closed in on Sudzha, a town of about 6,000 people six miles from the Ukrainian-Russian border.

item.title: After Haniyeh’s Death, Hamas Gets a Show of Support in the West Bank
item.description: After Hamas’s political leader was killed, some honored him in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, where a rival Palestinian faction is dominant.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Demonstrators waved Hamas flags last week in the city of Hebron in the Israeli-occupied West Bank after Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas political leader, was assassinated in Iran.

item.title: Making House Calls to Mongolia’s Herders
item.description: This is how Mongolia provides basic medical services to its far-flung, semi-nomadic populations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Liverpool Sends a Message to Far-Right Rioters: Not Here
item.description: The city in northern England has a long history of protest. That tradition continued this week, with counterprotesters delivering a firm rejection of anti-immigrant violence.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: 3rd Teenager Arrested Over Planned Attack on Taylor Swift’s Vienna Concerts
item.description: The authorities said the 18-year-old was connected to the main suspect and had recently sworn allegiance to the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers looking down over a crowd of Taylor Swift fans in central Vienna on Thursday.

item.title: Doug Emhoff Stresses a Personal Push Against Antisemitism
item.description: At an event in Paris to commemorate a 1982 attack on a Jewish deli there, Kamala Harris’s husband said, “Part of fighting hate is living openly and proudly as a Jew.”
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Doug Emhoff, Vice President Kamala Harris’s husband, ordering lunch at a falafel restaurant in Paris on Friday. He has emerged as the Biden administration’s most visible face in the struggle against antisemitism.

item.title: Belarus Shuns Athletes Who Protested Lukashenko
item.description: Many elite athletes who spoke against their autocratic leader must watch on the sidelines while those who stayed quiet or showed loyalty compete in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristina Timanovskaya was able to change her citizenship from Belarusian to Polish to compete in the Paris Games.

item.title: Plane Crashes Near São Paulo, Brazil, Killing 61 Onboard
item.description: The Brazilian authorities said no one survived the crash, outside São Paulo on Friday afternoon. The airline, VoePass, said the cause was unknown.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Paulo Motoryn and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Felipe Magalhaes Filho, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image taken from video purportedly shows a home burning after being struck by part of an airplane that crashed on Friday in Vinhedo, Brazil.

item.title: The Paris Bridge of Olympic Joy and Its Violent Past
item.description: The Pont du Carrousel, gathering place of joyous crowds, has come to symbolize a season of magic. It was not always so.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pont du Carrousel, in the center of Paris, has always been a place for lovers to linger and visitors to lose themselves, and never more so than during these Olympics.

item.title: After a Brief Appearance, Carles Puigdemont Flees Spain Again. Why?
item.description: The Catalan separatist leader, who has been living in self-imposed exile since a failed independence bid, vanished almost as quickly as he surfaced this week. Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont, center, on Thursday in Barcelona, where he addressed a rally near the regional Parliament.

item.title: How the Olympics Warp Time
item.description: Doesn’t it seem like the Paris Games have gone by fast? Imagine having your success or failure defined by thousandths of a second.
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Dear Pentathletes: Enjoy Your Last Ride. Get Ready for the Obstacle Course.
item.description: Pentathlon will trade show jumping for an obstacle course in 2028, after accusations of horse mistreatment in Tokyo. Athletes aren’t thrilled. But they could have been pillow fighting.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Athletes at the Paris Games are competing in show jumping as a part of modern pentathlon for the final time.

item.title: Israel Launches Another Offensive in Gaza’s South Amid Push for Truce
item.description: The United States, Egypt and Qatar are trying to restart peace talks between Hamas and Israel, while Israel carries on its operation in Gaza and braces for attacks by Iran and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Ameera Harouda, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A Palestinian youth flees the Khan Younis area of the Gaza Strip, following evacuation orders from the Israeli military, which staged an offensive there.

item.title: Imane Khelif Tunes Out the Distractions to Win Gold
item.description: Khelif weathered two weeks of distractions, breezing to the gold medal in women’s boxing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das and Gabriela Bhaskar
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: B-Girl Raygun, an Australian Professor, Turned Breaking on Its Head
item.description: Rachael Gunn, known as B-girl Raygun, displayed some … unique moves as she competed in a field with breakers half her age. The judges and the internet were underwhelmed.
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart and Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: During the round robin on Friday, Rachael Gunn, also known as B-girl Raygun, performed a move that looked something like swimming and another that could best be described as duckwalking.

item.title: Should Soccer Make Space for Other Sports?
item.description: The saturation of soccer can be suffocating for the rest of the athletic landscape.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Erling Haaland’s summer included a tour of the United States. Next up? The Charity Shield on Saturday.

item.title: Here Are the 2024 Olympic Moments We Won’t Forget
item.description: It doesn’t take a medal to make a lasting memory.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Olympic Breaking’s Key Player Is a D.J. From Brooklyn
item.description: Stephen Fleg will help provide the soundtrack for a new sport’s Olympic debut. He gets to pick the songs, and the competitors have no idea what he’ll play.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Brittainy Newman
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times

item.title: Philippines Appeals Court Restores Rappler’s Business License
item.description: The case, brought after Rappler was singled out by former President Rodrigo Duterte, was one of many facing the outlet and its co-founder, the Nobel laureate Maria Ressa.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Maria Ressa, the co-founder of the news site Rappler, speaking to journalists in Manila in 2023. An appeals court on Friday called for Rappler’s revoked license to be restored.

item.title: About 400 Million People Worldwide Have Had Long Covid, Researchers Say
item.description: The condition has put significant strain on patients and society — at a global economic cost of about $1 trillion a year, a new report estimates.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:description: Cots placed outside the Washington Monument in 2023 to represent people suffering from long Covid and ME/CFS. A new study estimates 400 million people worldwide have had long Covid and says the global economic cost is $1 trillion a year.

item.title: Olympic Marathon Course Is Toughest Ever for a Major Race
item.description: “Oh, my gosh,” one Olympian gasped when she got her first look at the hilly, demanding course. “This looks ridiculous.”
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympic marathon course will send runners up steep hills and then down again.

item.title: A Pastry That Tastes Like Home
item.description: The cheese scone is so essential to the New Zealand diet that it is almost impossible to find a cafe without a plate of them on the counter.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Pete McKenzie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheese scones for Floriditas cafe, fresh out of the oven. The savory baked good is popular in New Zealand, but hard to find elsewhere.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Plans for a Harris-Trump debate.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida yesterday.

item.title: Israel Prepares for Expected Attacks by Iran and Hezbollah
item.description: Israel advised people to stock up on food and water in fortified safe rooms, while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told soldiers that Israel is “prepared for defense, as well as offense.”
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Tel Aviv on Thursday. Israel is on high alert.

item.title: Biden and Leaders of Qatar and Egypt Plan ‘Final’ Cease-Fire Proposal
item.description: The leaders said “the time has come” to conclude a deal between Israel and Hamas, insisting that the negotiators meet in Cairo or Doha next Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Smoke rising after Israeli strikes in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Thursday.

item.title: Sydney McLaughlin breaks her own 400-meter hurdle record. Again.
item.description: Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone broke her own world record on her way to winning gold for the United States in the 400 meter hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg, Chang W. Lee, Gabriela Bhaskar and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Jacques Lewis, French Veteran of U.S. Landing on D-Day, Dies at 105
item.description: Believed to be the last surviving Frenchman to wade ashore with Americans, he was attached to an Army unit that stormed Utah Beach and helped drive Germans out of France.
item.dc:creator: Phil Davison
item.media:description: Jacques Lewis on June 8 attending a ceremony at the Arc de Triomphe in Paris marking the 80th anniversary of D-Day.

item.title: Noah Lyles Wins Bronze in 200 Meters, Then Reveals He Has Covid
item.description: Lyles said he started feeling ill two days ago and knew it was more than just soreness from winning the 100. In Paris, there are no testing requirements, and national governing bodies develop their own protocols.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: Noah Lyles struggled after finishing third in the men’s 200-meter dash.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Trump and Harris Agreed to Debate
item.description: Plus, how Olympians get paid.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida yesterday.

item.title: Every 4 Years, Timmy McCarthy Gives Ireland a Reason to Watch Basketball
item.description: While the Irish have no team in the Olympic tournament, Timmy McCarthy’s eccentric, enthusiastic commentary has earned him his own fervent fan base.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: Taylor Swift Fans Commiserate in Vienna After Concerts Are Canceled
item.description: Taylor Swift fans from around the world grappled with disappointment and fear after a terrorism plot derailed the Vienna dates of the Eras Tour.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: Fans in central Vienna on Thursday. The planned concerts had been estimated to draw 200,000 Swifties from around the world.

item.title: Free Haircuts and Manicures for Athletes at the Olympic Village Salon
item.description: At the Olympic Village, cuts, styles and manicures are free. The benefits, the athletes say, are priceless.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Athletes at the salon in the Olympic Village in St.-Ouen-sur-Seine, France.

item.title: Jake Paul Lends His Celebrity (Some of It) to Olympic Boxing
item.description: Paul, a social media influencer and boxer, usually promotes professional fighting. Now he’s in a partnership with U.S.A. Boxing, but his output in Paris has been minimal.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan and Ryan Lowry

item.title: Olympic Medals Offer Ukraine a Brief Respite From War
item.description: Ukraine has won 10 medals so far at the Paris Olympics. Each has been celebrated in the war-torn country as a symbol of resilience and defiance.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Khyzhniak celebrated after winning the gold medal at the Paris Olympics on Wednesday.

item.title: 2 Youths Planned Attacks on Taylor Swift’s Vienna Concerts, Authorities Say
item.description: A suspect confessed to a plot using explosives and other weapons to kill as many attendees as possible, security officials said. The singer’s three-concert Vienna run was canceled.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Visitors talked to security staff outside the Ernst Happel Stadium in Vienna on Thursday after all three Taylor Swift concerts set to take place there were canceled.

item.title: How Anti-Immigrant Riots Flared in the U.K.
item.description: A far-right movement fueled by disinformation has brought fear and violence to cities across England and in Northern Ireland. That has in turn prompted counterprotests.
item.dc:creator: Nader Ibrahim and Peter Robins
item.media:description: In Rotherham, the police struggled to fend off rioters attacking a hotel.

item.title: In a Surprise, Ukraine Advances on Russian Region of Kursk
item.description: The local government in the Russian region of Kursk declared a state of emergency as military analysts reported that Ukrainian forces had advanced several miles across the border.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A photo provided by the acting governor in the Kursk region of Russia shows a house this week that was damaged by Ukrainian shelling.

item.title: U.K. Officials Express Relief After Far-Right Riots Fail to Materialize
item.description: The authorities had been braced for further violence after anti-immigrant demonstrations in previous days had descended into riots.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Liverpool, England, on Wednesday. With around 6,000 police on standby across Britain, the evening passed with little violence.

item.title: U.S. ‘Dissatisfied’ With China’s Disclosures About Stabbings
item.description: The U.S. ambassador has criticized the handling of an attack on four instructors from an American college, but China’s foreign ministry called it an “isolated incident.”
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Park visitors in Jilin City, China, walking past the wall near where four instructors from an American college were stabbed on June 10.

item.title: Who Are the S.P.L.M., the Rebel Group Fighting for Democracy in Sudan?
item.description: We embedded with an elusive rebel group in the Nuba Mountains to document its side of the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey

item.title: Chinese Woman Loses Legal Challenge for Right to Freeze Her Eggs
item.description: Despite a declining birthrate that has alarmed the nation’s leaders, regulations in China prevent unmarried women from freezing their eggs.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Teresa Xu outside the Chaoyang court in 2021, before a hearing in her case against a hospital that rejected her request to freeze eggs.

item.title: What’s It Like to Be Drug-Tested? We Asked Three Olympic Runners.
item.description: It will never feel normal, athletes said, to have a stranger knock on your door and ask for a vial of your blood. Or some urine.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: Materials for an antidoping test. Track athletes must provide their locations so they can be tested without advance notice.

item.title: Why Kenya Stopped Running From Its Doping Past
item.description: A nation synonymous with distance running was given a multimillion-dollar choice: Get serious about antidoping efforts, or get banned from world sports.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Kenyan runners at a meet in Nairobi in 2018.

item.title: Tsunami Warning Issued in Japan After Strong Earthquakes
item.description: The official warning came after a 7.1-magnitude temblor struck off the coast of southern Japan on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Kiuko Notoya, Hisako Ueno and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Visitors to the Nagasaki Peace Park in western Japan as an earthquake alert was issued on Thursday.

item.title: Carles Puigdemont Returns to Catalonia, Defying Spanish Arrest Warrant
item.description: Large crowds greeted the former regional leader, who has lived in self-imposed exile since a failed 2017 independence bid. Despite a new amnesty law, he could still face arrest.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont, Catalonia’s separatist leader-in-exile, returned to Barcelona on Thursday.

item.title: Muhammad Yunus Set to Lead Bangladesh Temporarily
item.description: Muhammad Yunus, as interim leader, faces the daunting task of restoring order in a country gripped by violence and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Mohammed Shahabuddin, center, administering the oath of office late Thursday to Muhammad Yunus, in a vest at right, in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Antiracism protesters in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A demonstration in London yesterday against a planned anti-immigrant protest.

item.title: Why the Dutch Field Hockey Team Isn’t Shaking Hands at the Olympics
item.description: After two pandemic-disrupted Olympics, most teams haven’t given Covid a second thought in Paris. The one from the Netherlands is the exception.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith, Talya Minsberg and Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: The Netherlands team has avoided handshakes with competitors at the Olympics.

item.title: Trying to Capitalize on Anti-Migrant Riots Could Backfire on U.K.’s Far Right
item.description: The public’s reaction to the recent rioting has been resoundingly negative, suggesting that using the unrest to push anti-immigrant policies could backfire, at least in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Holding back demonstrators during disorder in Southport, northwestern England, last week.

item.title: Feud Flares Between U.S. and Global Antidoping Agency
item.description: American officials allowed athletes to compete after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs so they could work undercover. Their global counterparts call that a breach of the rules.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: “Clean athletes deserve answers, and they deserve better from WADA,” said Travis Tygart, the head of the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency, referring to the global doping watchdog.

item.title: Arab and Western Nations Urge Restraint as Israel-Iran Tensions Simmer
item.description: Trying to head off a Middle East war, several countries are pressing Iran to temper its retaliation for the assassination of a Hamas leader in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Ben Hubbard, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A banner showing the Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh, left, who was killed in an assassination last week, joining hands with Iran’s new president, Masoud Pezeshkian, in Tehran, Iran, on Monday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Antiracism Protesters Gather in Britain
item.description: Plus, China’s quest for Olympic gold shifts gears.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: North Finchley, a suburb of London, yesterday.
